title: Judges wait to decide if Boris Johnson’s Brexit letters to EU were unlawful
text:
Boris Johnson refused to sign the letter he sent the EU (Picture: AP)

Judges at Scotland’s highest court have delayed a decision on whether Boris Johnson fully complied with the Benn Act.

The act dictates that the Prime Minister must ask the EU for an extension to the Article 50 negotiation period if MPs do not support his deal.

At a hearing in the Court of Session, it was accepted that Boris has observed part of the legislation by sending a request letter to the EU.

However, he did not sign the document and also sent an accompanying letter, with his signature, stating that a delay would be a mistake.

The UK government argued that Boris fulfilled his obligations, stating that the appeal should therefore be dropped.

But campaigners, led by SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC, businessman Dale Vince and barrister Jolyon Maugham QC have now been granted their request to postpone any decision over whether the PM broke the law.

Three of Scotland’s most senior judges said the case should be continued until the Benn Act obligations have been complied with in full.

Jolyon Maugham said he was ‘delighted’ with the court’s decision (Picture: PA)

This includes waiting to see if a potential extension granted by the EU is accepted by Boris.

However, the case could still be voided if parliament accepts the withdrawal deal brought to them for a meaningful vote.

Mr Maugham said he was ‘delighted’ with the court’s decision, adding that the PM could not be trusted to ‘comply with the law’.

While Aidan O’Neill QC, representing the petitioners, said Boris’ choice to send an additional letter along with his request to the EU was ‘unusual’.

He added that the PM was ‘sailing close to the wind’ and operating ‘not entirely in accord with the spirit’ of the Act.

The court is expected to return to the case at a later date.

During the case’s first hearing on October 9, the government’s lawyers stated that Boris would adhere to the law in writing, despite his own declarations he would not be seeking an extension.

Another meaningful vote could go ahead today (Picture: AFP)

It was then postponed until after the deadline for the extension request to the sent.

European Commission president Donald Tusk confirmed at 10pm on Saturday that he had received the documents from the PM.

He is now in the process of ‘consulting EU leaders’ on how to react.

House of Commons Speaker John Bercow is expected to announce today whether the government will hold a meaningful vote on the Brexit deal.

However, Downing Street have said they could pull today’s vote if more delaying amendments are selected for debate.

A ‘Letwin 2’ amendment is expected to be tabled by a group of former Tory MPs if the Speaker does allow the vote to go ahead.
